content: 911 dispatchers are a vital link between the caller and police, fire departments/EMTs and ambulances! They deserve recognition, yet are rarely complimented for the important job they do! Keep smiling, everyone will wonder what you've been up to!
reply: 911 dispatchers are a vital link between the caller and police, fire departments/EMTs and ambulances! They deserve recognition, yet are rarely complimented for the important job they do! Keep smiling, everyone will wonder what you've been up to!
title: A  salute to all 911 dispatchers!

title: A  salute to all 911 dispatchers!

content: I've had a number of occasions to call 911, the dispatcher taking the call remained calm and professional. They stay on the phone with you until help arrives! Keep smiling, everyone will wonder what you've been up to!
reply: I've had a number of occasions to call 911, the dispatcher taking the call remained calm and professional. They stay on the phone with you until help arrives! Keep smiling, everyone will wonder what you've been up to!

title: A  salute to all 911 dispatchers!

content: I don't care for the term dispatcher. The work leans more towards managing resources. With shrinking budgets and increasing workloads, almost every communtiy is subscibing to the theme of doing more work with less people. Asssignments are backed up sometimes for hours while priorities are answered first. Nobody is happy and dispatchers are the first to receive the backlash from cops and citizens. Several years ago we had a lieutenant shot to death making a DWI arrest. The bum who did it met the same fate 20 minutes later when he was pulled over again. With everything going on I'll never forget what I heard on the radio. The dispatchers were crying as they continued to provide all their support.
reply: I don't care for the term dispatcher. The work leans more towards managing resources. With shrinking budgets and increasing workloads, almost every communtiy is subscibing to the theme of doing more work with less people. Several years ago we had a lieutenant shot to death making a DWI arrest. The bum who did it met the same fate 20 minutes later when he was pulled over again. With everything going on I'll never forget what I heard on the radio. The dispatchers were crying as they continued to provide all their support.
title: A  salute to all 911 dispatchers!

content: I was a 911 Dispatcher before my 3rd child was born and I will agree that it is a vital position. In a county that hadn't caught up technology-wise, I was Dispatch for City and County and anything else in a 20 mile radius (including Highway Patrol). I have some stories that would make you really wonder what this world's coming to. I'm in school for Criminal Justice and I plan to go back, but to the other side of the Radio, as a Deputy/Officer. I LOVED everyday of being a Dispatcher! It was the best job I've EVER had (aside from being a Mommy of course)
reply: I was a 911 Dispatcher before my 3rd child was born and I will agree that it is a vital position. In a county that hadn't caught up technology-wise, I was Dispatch for City and County and anything else in a 20 mile radius (including Highway Patrol). I have some stories that would make you really wonder what this world's coming to. I'm in school for Criminal Justice and I plan to go back, but to the other side of the Radio, as a Deputy/Officer. I LOVED everyday of being a Dispatcher! It was the best job I've EVER had (aside from being a Mommy of course)
title: A  salute to all 911 dispatchers!

content: The last time I called 911 was after I heard the sound outside my Apt of a head hitting the ground. The 911 operator was more interested in who I was instead of telling me that help was on the way. I hung up on her and went outside to render assistance myself. Even though I had already given the location of the incident, it took a long time for the ambulance to arrive. The woman later died in the emergency department.
reply: The last time I called 911 was after I heard the sound outside my Apt of a head hitting the ground. The 911 operator was more interested in who I was instead of telling me that help was on the way. I hung up on her and went outside to render assistance myself. Even though I had already given the location of the incident, it took a long time for the ambulance to arrive. The woman later died in the emergency department.
title: A  salute to all 911 dispatchers!

content: Ambulances are for just these things, emergencies as you described. However more times than not they are called for nonsense transport cases where the patients could drive themselves. Many times there's 3 cars in the their driveway, but they demand an ambulance. This results a strain in the system where units are tied up as taxi cabs, while somebody else is fighting to breathe with a heart attack.
reply: Ambulances are for just these things, emergencies as you described. However more times than not they are called for nonsense transport cases where the patients could drive themselves. Many times there's 3 cars in the their driveway, but they demand an ambulance. This results a strain in the system where units are tied up as taxi cabs, while somebody else is fighting to breathe with a heart attack.
title: A  salute to all 911 dispatchers!

content: quote: I hung up on her why?
reply: why?
title: A  salute to all 911 dispatchers!

content: You'll forgive my forthcoming statement, but it's my opinion: People who don't do the job, don't get why Dispatchers do the things they do (on a call). Hanging up can be more of a hindrance than a help. Asking for your info. is part of the helping process. To ascertain if a call is valid or not saves precious resources. Hanging up can cause a call to seem invalid. PLEASE PLEASE don't call 911 and then hang up. If they need info from YOU to further the help process, just give it. Dispatchers aren't trying to chit chat like ladies at Tea, they're asking the questions they were TRAINED to ask.
reply: You'll forgive my forthcoming statement, but it's my opinion: People who don't do the job, don't get why Dispatchers do the things they do (on a call). content: Tonight a 59 yr old gentleman called 911 stating he was mad at the government. He said: 1) The government is killing all the squirrels. 2) Someone is trying to poison his entire family. 3) And he wants all his neighbors hung. It sounded funny at first, but it turned sour quickly. He went the hard way. Oh well!

Who I am was not relevant, they hand my name and address on caller ID. The unconscious patient was the focus. I hung up to go and try to help her. The 911 woman gave me no indication that assistance was enroute. "When you look into an abyss, the abyss also looks into you." ~~ Friedrich Nietzsche

content: You'll forgive my forthcoming statement, but it's my opinion: People who don't do the job, don't get why Dispatchers do the things they do (on a call). Hanging up can be more of a hindrance than a help. Asking for your info. is part of the helping process. To ascertain if a call is valid or not saves precious resources. Hanging up can cause a call to seem invalid. PLEASE PLEASE don't call 911 and then hang up. If they need info from YOU to further the help process, just give it. Dispatchers aren't trying to chit chat like ladies at Tea, they're asking the questions they were TRAINED to ask.
reply: You'll forgive my forthcoming statement, but it's my opinion: People who don't do the job, don't get why Dispatchers do the things they do (on a call).
